text: Thank you, Chair Page. I apologize in advance if I freeze. I've sent a copy of it to Mr. Elkaro, so he might, if I freeze all the way out, then maybe he can pick up the pieces. But I think it was on May 7, 2020, nearly 40 school board meetings ago, the acronym COVID  for students and families, our staff, and our broader community has been the board and for our entire school division. The good news is that while there has been some 185 confirmed cases of COVID among our students, staff, and  school, there have been few cases of virus transmission inside our schools. Today, nearly three out of four of our eligible students are fully vaccinated, and in the first few weeks of our vaccination clinics last spring, nearly 2,000 of our employees received vaccines. In little over one week, we will open our schools to more than 13,000 students.  with the confidence that the mitigation strategies and practices we have implemented relating to cleaning, air quality, spacing and masking are under continuous review, as well as new policies being considered, all are designed to keep our students and staff as safe as possible and to permit in-school learning.  An important resource for these achievements has been a volunteer advisory panel of medical experts who have unselfishly donated their time and expertise in keeping our educational community safe. For example, they review our mitigation plans and strategies for sufficiency. They provide real-time evidence-based data and information that allows us to deal  with a myriad of challenges. They support our vaccination efforts, including volunteering at our clinics and communicating with our families. They join public meetings like this one to discuss COVID protection practices. They directly support our school nurses on triage decisions, and they are nearly always available to deliver ongoing counsel to school administrators and to the members of this board as we continue to navigate the challenges of COVID.  I'd like to publicly recognize this superb team of medical experts, which includes Drs. Jeff Vergalis, Paige Perriello, and Carlos Armengol. Before asking each of our guests to say a few words, I know we will be sending letters of appreciation to each of you and to the members of our Student Health Advisory Board. I want to tell you how grateful we all are.  for your public service and for the lives you have helped protect against the COVID-19 virus. We have a COVID update shortly on our agenda, but we will welcome some thoughts from our medical experts on the current challenges we face. Dr. Vigalist, would you like to go first?
speaker: kateacuff

text: I would thank you guys very much. Hopefully everybody can see and hear me without any problem. Dr. Acuff that was a wonderful introduction and I am, you know, probably would like the first thing for me to say is to kind of give it, give it back to you guys and to say that I have had the, I guess I would use the word privilege but the unfortunate privilege over the last year and a half of  advising multiple organizations that deal with kids, both in this state and in other states. And I am not just saying that because I'm almost on the school board right now, but I can't begin to tell you how impressed I am with you guys and the superintendent's office, especially all the way down to the school nurses. And a big, big thank you to Eileen Gomez, who is a massive asset to this county and to the school district.  I can't even begin to continue on and on. I absolutely believe that you the reason that some of the success and most of the success that you guys were able to have a lot last year with COVID mitigation is because of the team that Dr. Haas has on down and and I'm not I promise you I'm not saying that I've just been I've been dealt with a lot of other organizations that don't nearly have the logistics put together.  I've had the privilege of being able to address this group on a couple of occasions and obviously every time I'm kind of known to saying what, what do we know and what do we don't know. Because as we go along in this pandemic. I think one of the important things is, is that the science changes and it changes as we learn more and more information as it goes on. There's a couple of big key points that I want to  remind us about that we learned last year as I kind of set up my colleagues, Dr. Perriello, as well as Dr. Armengol. And one of the biggest things that I think I want everybody to remember that is the statistics that Dr. Acuff put forward in the beginning. There were almost 180 cases of COVID in the school district last year among staff, students, and other contractors that worked. That led to over 500 individuals being quarantined for safety.  I remember though, we had virtually no secondary spread last year, none. And more importantly, we had definitely no secondary spread from other students to other students. There was a lot of fear going into the school year last year that we would see that schools were a big super spreader area or a big area that we see, especially like when we see with influenza that would spread disease. And the fact of the matter is, is that it is the skills and the mitigation strategies that were put in place  Here in a CPS that was able to create the abilities for schools to be safe. We cannot prevent disease from coming into school I wish we could, that would put me out of business as a physician very quickly. However, what we can do is that we can prevent it from spreading and I think you guys are a testament to that.  I would like to say that ACPS is the best in the country. But thankfully, the science would also back up that that was true across all school districts that we were able to see. Now, you are going to find isolated incidences in various areas across the country that struggled and found outbreaks. But we are seeing time and time again from many well-done and well-controlled studies that if the proper mitigation strategies are put in place, that success can be had. And I think that's probably the biggest lesson that I want  kind of everybody to continue to understand is that we know we can control this within schools, we have the tools to do it, you have the team in place to be able to do it. And you have a huge, huge group of volunteer, you know, people that are willing and supporting you every step of the way.  Finally, I want to leave you kind of with a glimpse of what we all know that we're dealing with right now, which is this concept of how the Delta variant changes the facts a little bit. As a quick 30-second aside, we are used to variants in viruses. Variants in viruses is not an uncommon thing. This is the reason that you have to get a flu shot every year is because the virus mutates every year and we're dealing with a new strain.  COVID, the SARS-CoV-2 virus doesn't mutate quite as fast, but there has still been over multiple thousands of variants that have been identified of this virus across the world. Why we hear of certain ones that get called is because it becomes a quote, variant of interest, and that it grabs hold. It seems to be something that does something a little bit different. And that's where we end up getting the alpha, the gamma, the delta. It's kind of a similar concept to how we deal with  Tropical storms and hurricanes to some degree that when it becomes an interesting one, it's something that we track a little bit more closely. What we've been finding about Delta is that it's little niche is that it has extreme contagiousness. And that is the thing that we have been dealing with in public health circles is that it seems to be drastically more contagious than the other variants that have come before it.  Thankfully, we also have a lot of good evidence both taking from states that are in a much worse shape than we are in addition to other countries that are about three to four weeks ahead of it, but it doesn't seem to be especially in children and young adults causing any more significant illness.  And that's an important patch to kind of remember is that we know as a general rule that it is more contagious, but we are not seeing significant more illness, we are seeing a significant higher number of illness but that's because we are seeing more and more children. And that's mainly because of unvaccinated as well as dealing with the fact that it's spreading a little bit easier right now.  But I want to understand that this is not a new disease. It is not something that we are all of a sudden seeing things that we cannot do for it. And much more importantly, as I'm going to kind of toss this now to Dr Perry yellow is that the mitigation strategies that we have in place work wonderfully for it.  as they work for any respiratory virus that we really have. And so that's the kind of key to understand is that in our mindset, the Delta variant does not change the outcomes that we think that we would be able to have in schools. But it does put an onus on us to continue to stay focused on the strategies that we put in place as a school district. So I'm going to leave it now to my partner and colleague, Dr. Perriello. And again, I  I want to thank you guys for the opportunity to help, and much more importantly to say that this is, you know, kind of the start of something that will continue to always have your back and always be able to assist in any way that we can.
speaker: jeffvergale

text: Thank you all. Thank you all for having us and just echo Dr. Vergeles.  Thanks, it was really meaningful to us as pediatricians that you all have included us in this process. This is, you know, kind of what we do every day and I think Elmer County was one of the first school systems to reach out and really start.  having pediatricians help, and we've been grateful, and I think the partnership has been particularly valuable. One of the great things, as Dr. Vergalis just outlined, is that we got to experience last year and learn about what mitigation strategies work. I think that Albemarle County schools were maybe the first to go ahead and put out their universal masking this year, which was incredibly beneficial  To have that out there, we think it's incredibly important, particularly as we go into the Delta variant time where we know contagiousness is such a factor. And we were able to learn last year that masks really do work to keep our kids safe, our staff and teachers safe, and keep our schools open. And I would say as pediatricians that the most important thing to us, and we appreciate that you all have had this on the forefront as well,  is to have kids have as many in person days of school this year as possible. These mitigation strategies are going to allow us to do that. So, you know, masking the ventilation efforts that the school system has gone to using some distance being outside whenever you can, of course handwashing.  And some basic hygiene things, as well as vaccination for as many 12 and up folks in the school that we can have all those things together are really going to be incredibly useful. We all hope, particularly in our high schools.  where everybody in the high school is able to be vaccinated, that we can start talking about something different at some point, but we are clearly not in that moment. And we are really grateful for this great set of mitigation strategies going into the new year. I think Dr. Armengol is gonna talk a little bit about vaccine.
speaker: paigeperriello

text: Page Nod, if you can hear me.  Okay, great. I'm sorry, I'm having some technological difficulties. My apologies, I don't have a camera, which I very much dislike, but I just wanted to let everybody know on the board that we're very appreciative. Thank Dr. Acuff for her very nice words. It's very appreciated. I just wanted to mention that one of the tools that we have in our toolbox this year that we really didn't have until really late last year is the vaccination.  I know everyone who has not had one is concerned about the safety and the fact that it came so fast. But this vaccine has been a miracle, really. It was developed in under a year. It was developed with very good science. And I don't know of any vaccine that's ever had so many doses given in such a short time. I would say over 200 million doses right here in the United States.  and thus far it's proved to be rather safe. And I just wanna underscore to the families out there who've been a little reluctant that they should go ahead and get their vaccine. It's really important. The pandemic has become a pandemic of the unvaccinated. If you look at the hospital numbers, it's clear that 98 to 99% of those being admitted to the hospital are unvaccinated.  The same is true of those who are dying. And just in the last two weeks or less, the number of patients admitted to the UVA hospital has doubled. And I don't see an end to that. I think it's gonna get worse before it gets better. And the way to prevent that is for as many people as possibly can get their vaccine. Of course, not everyone can get a vaccination. The current vaccine is authorized for use in kids 12 and up  The one that we use in that age group is the Pfizer vaccine, which is a two-dose vaccine. It's given three weeks apart. It's available pretty much anywhere that you want to get it, including numerous doctor's offices, the health department, numerous mobile clinics. They'll even come out to your home and do it at your home if you have an inability to get around. And that can be arranged through the health department.  So there's really, I think we've tried to remove as many obstacles as possible to getting the vaccine. Everyone is curious about when the children under 12 will get vaccinated. We are as well. We're fortunate at our office that we're participating in the study for the Pfizer vaccine in that age group. We have a little bit of an insight on that. And unfortunately,  Unlike what you've seen in the press here lately, we do not expect to see authorization of the vaccine in the kids under 12 until December. The FDA has requested a four to six month period of data collection. And we can tell you that the kids who were enrolled in the study in that age group did not complete their series until early to mid July and thus,  if you count four to six months from there, that takes you into early winter. I'd like to think it would come faster and sooner, and maybe something will happen to allow that. But realistically, I think we're looking at early winter before we're vaccinating the kids under 11. And so I think, as I said earlier, this is one more tool in the toolbox.  The way to prevent spread in the schools is to continue using all the tools in the toolbox. And that includes all the mitigation strategies that Dr. Perriello has mentioned already, plus using the vaccination where we can. I'll return it back to you all.

text: Thank you, Dr. Haas. Good evening, I'm Debbie Collins, Deputy Superintendent. We wanted to share some final information from our summer learning programming that occurred during July. Our average weekly attendance for our elementary students was 1,360 students, with our highest numbers in our primary grades  K and one. Our weekly average for our middle school students was 685 students, which is approximately 300 students more than we served at our middle schools in the past years. Our highest attendance numbers were in the sixth grade. For our high schools, we had approximately 450 students earn a new credit and 315 students recover credits from the 2020-21 school year. While I know that numbers tell one story,  I wanted to share with you some pictures that show the enthusiasm and engaged learning that occurred over the summer. I think Jennifer will share a video with you right now.
speaker: debbiecollins

text: I'd just like to echo the last slide that you saw.
speaker: michellecox

text: Thank you to our teachers, staff, and partners for a wonderful summer learning opportunity for our students. And thank you to the communications department for the pictures and the video. This information will be posted on our summer learning web page. Thank you.
speaker: debbiecollins

text: Thank you, Ms. Collins. I really appreciate that.  I believe our next announcement is from Dr. Kaiser regarding a wrap up on new teacher academy and a hiring update.
speaker: matthewhaas

text: Thank you, Dr. Haas, and thank you, board members. It is my pleasure to come to you tonight to talk to you about one of the most exciting things that I always look forward to each year, and that is when we welcome our new teachers to our new Teacher Academy. Beginning on Tuesday of this week, we welcomed about 180 new teachers to Albemarle County Public Schools in MTA. During these four days, our teachers are introduced to both their schools and the school division.  These teachers have had the opportunity to learn about the priorities of the school division to include an introduction into the goals of our new strategic plan. During the division part of NTA, the teachers have participated in a number of different activities to help them learn about ACPS curriculum and related instructional resources that they will be able to use with their students. They've been introduced to our culturally responsive teaching model, and they've learned about technology that they can use to integrate into their lessons.  Two consultants will be have joined or will be joining us for NTA. Mr. Dan Mulligan joined us yesterday and today to provide resources and strategies to engage students in learning.  And on Friday, Dr. Sean Woodley, a motivational speaker, will share ways to connect with students in learning. I would like to thank Mr. Page for his warm welcome to the new teachers on Tuesday, and to the lead coaches, equity specialists, learning technology integrators, and professional development staff for the work that they have done to plan and deliver a great introduction into Albemarle County Schools.  With that, I'm also going to transition to just a very brief hiring update. One of the things that we will do is in a future board meeting the human resources team will come and give a much more detailed look at the hiring for this current school year.  So as I shared with the new Teacher Academy information, we've hired about 180 new teachers at this point. We still have about 18 more to hire prior to the start of the school year, and our principals are working hard to fill these positions with highly qualified teachers. And I do anticipate that most, and I'm hoping all, of these positions will be filled as we begin the year with students.  This is the first year that we have been noticeably touched by the national teacher shortage, we are seeing much smaller than typical job pools across all levels and content areas, and very unusually we've seen drops in applicants for elementary teaching positions as well as English and social studies teachers, all of those areas are ones where we typically have very robust job.  filled positions as per usual include special education, world language and science teachers. I will say, though, even with the smaller job pools we have been able to hire an incredibly talented and diverse group of teachers who we know will provide rich learning experiences for our students.  We also have hired a number of new employees in our support services departments, but like we've seen with the teachers we are also feeling the impact of smaller job pools, as we continue to work to fill positions for school nurses and teaching assistants for bus drivers for child nutrition building services and et and edtp edtp staff.  Hiring and training is ongoing, and we are hopeful that our vacancies in these areas will be minimal as we begin the school year. As I said, this was intended to just be an overview for you, and I look forward to sharing more information with you in an upcoming meeting.

text: I'm going to start off by reading the public comment guidelines.  The School Board invites and actively seeks the public's input in the matters relevant to School Board governance and provides for time during its business meetings to hear from Albemarle County residents and community members. As authorized by Ordinance of the County of Albemarle, the School Board will hold its meetings electronically during the COVID-19 pandemic. The School Board is still committed to encouraging public comment, and so for this reason, there will be two ways for the public to provide comment.  First, as always, written comments may be submitted to the school board clerk prior to the start of the meeting will be given to all of the school board members for review. Second, actually, I should say, and also you can email us, you can always email us and email the school board directly, the members are as a group. And then second or third, as long as the school board holds its meeting electronically, members of the public wishing to provide public comment during the meeting may sign up online by 2pm the day of the meeting.  Tonight we have 18 speakers and they've all been notified that the speaking time has been reduced from three minutes to two minutes. So speakers will be notified when they reach the one minute mark. The notification is just me holding up a finger, so look out for it. And then their comments will conclude when they reach two minutes.  So before electronic public comment commences, I will try to announce the three speakers at a time. And I believe we'll be letting them into the room as they're getting prepared to speak. So if you are following on the live feed, there's a little bit of a delay. So please be paying attention to if you're getting let into the room and turn off your live feed once you're in the meeting so that you're listening to it as it's happening. That's caused issues in the past.  So speakers during the meeting are those submitting rank comments should state their name and address our magisterial district, our school. Further speakers should try to limit comments or should limit comments to those matters that are relevant to school board governance or the operations of the school division. Lastly, although the school board will not respond to comments made during the public comment period, school board members may address comments at the end of the meeting agenda under other business. So with that, we'll move over to  the sign up sheet, and I have the first three speakers as Joe Rice, Nikki Athey, and Mary Mirzajewski. So Joe Rice, I will see if I see him in here.

text: Sure. Hi, my name is Joe Rice, and I live in the Ravenna District.  I am speaking as a concerned parent, a civil servant, and a citizen. The data I am providing comes directly from the latest CDC, VDH, and BRHD data portals. My wife and I have three children in ACPS schools, and we have been virtual schooling since it was made available to us last school year. We understand the importance of children being in school for social and mental health development. And last spring, we were very much looking forward to attending school this fall as vaccinations were increasing and COVID case counts were falling.  However, that was then, and this is Delta. In the last few weeks, organizations have had to pivot in response to rapidly increasing COVID cases in our district. As parents, we were once again concerned about the prospect of returning to school with the more contagious Delta variant taking hold in our community. We were pleased that the virtual school option was made available once more in case we changed our minds. But like other families, we did not want to make a rash decision in response to early rising numbers.  When ACPS sent us the email on July 30th, giving us seven days to decide the schooling future for our children, the rate of cases was 43 per 100,000 persons. text: So my name is Julie Govan. I'm in the Samuel Miller District. I have four kids in Albemarle County Schools. I was recently standing in front of Albemarle High School, reading the sign memorializing the Albemarle 26, the students who desegregated Albemarle schools after massive resistance. And the obvious thing I thought about was the courage and the determination of those students  But then I also thought about another set of people, and I thought about the students and parents who were fearful of that change. They had been raised with teachings that gave them reasons to fear, they thought. Their church leaders even, in some cases, conveyed to them that fully inclusive schools were dangerous and bad and counter to their religion. They learned eventually that there was nothing to fear, and many later expressed regret.  So I'm speaking because this is our chance to not have the same regret, to not make their mistakes, to not let fear dictate policy. These students, these transgender and gender expansive students, they are part of our community and they have been for years. They're already using bathrooms in our schools. They're the children our children went to preschool with and played soccer with and splashed in the pool with.  This policy will change almost nothing for kids who are not trans, but it will make all the difference in the world for our children's peers who are trans, who are gender expansive, to know they are seen, heard, and accepted by their school. I have heard commenters ask us not to rush to act. This doesn't seem like a rush because it's taking years for schools to step towards supporting and affirming transgender and gender expansive students.  Child centric policies are important. And I came here tonight to thank Albemarle County for their work in understanding how important this is and understanding the needs of these students. Thank you.

text: All right, good evening board members. I'm Pat McLaughlin, chief of strategic planning for the school division. And I'm here tonight to provide a COVID-19 status update and also to provide you with the latest information on our mitigation plan as we prepare to begin the school year in just a couple of weeks. Also with me tonight is Eileen Gomez, our school nurse coordinator who can provide some insights into any questions you may have. So let's get started.  Tonight's update will look a bit different from the updates you have been receiving over the course of the pandemic as we are aligning our update to the most recent guidance provided to us from the Virginia Department of Health. As all public schools in Virginia are now required to open five days a week for in-person instruction, the guidance is no longer geared toward the conditions under which schools should be open for students. The newly updated guidance instead provides five steps for school divisions to consider as operational decisions are made  for enduring the 2021 2022 school year. The first of these steps is to evaluate the level of community disease transmission at the local level. So the level of community transmission is determined using two measures.  The first is the total number of new cases per 100,000 people in the past seven days. The most recent data we have is from Tuesday, August 10th. And at that time, our current seven day total per 100,000 people was 92.38, putting us at the substantial transmission category. The second measure is the percent of NAAT tests that are positive during the past seven days. And our latest percent positivity is 4.4%  which puts us in the low transmission category for the VDH. When the two indicators are at different levels, the VDH recommends that you use the indicator with the higher value as your community transmission level. So our current transmission level is at the substantial level. The second step they recommend is understand the community level of vaccination coverage.  I'm happy to say that our levels of community vaccination among eligible school level students school age students is one of the higher we've seen in the state and Albemarle County 78.2 of 12 to 15 year olds and 83.2 of 16 to seven year olds have had at least received at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine.  Our fully vaccinated numbers for our 12 to 15 and our 16 to 17 year old age groups are 68.5 and 75.8 respectively. Step number three in the operational decision making is to consider the level of impact that the virus is having in our schools.  So you may recall this matrix from previous COVID updates. It asks us to look at levels of transmission in our schools, how the virus is impacting student absenteeism and our staff's capacity to attend school. This level of impact can only be determined when schools are open and operational. And since we're currently closed for summer break, we can't determine a level of impact on our schools at this time. So this information will be provided in future updates to the board once our students return later in the month.  Step number four is to understand the capacity and needs of our community and our school. And for this step, the VDH advises that schools should prioritize providing safety-optimized in-person learning environments. Schools will need to assess the feasibility of certain prevention strategies to help decide what combination of strategies is best.  With that advice in mind, our teams are continually examining our capacity, our needs, and our layered mitigation strategies, which leads us to the final step in the process, which is to determine and implement a layered approach with multiple prevention strategies. The VDH recommends that all schools and school divisions work with their local public health departments to assist in determining the layered prevention strategies that are needed.  We have done this since the start of the pandemic through our continued partnership with the Blue Ridge Health District and with the local medical professionals, some of which you heard from earlier this evening. There are nine key prevention strategies that the VDH has outlined, and they include promoting vaccination, consistent and correct use of masks, physical distancing, screening testing, ventilation, hand washing and respiratory etiquette, cleaning and maintaining healthy facilities,  staying home when sick and getting tested, and contact tracing in combination with isolation and quarantine. We have had and will continue to have all of these strategies in place with the exception of screening testing, which we have been advised by our partners would have a limited benefit to containing the spread of the virus.  We're following all of the recommendations put forth by the VDH to make our school environments as safe as possible for our students and staff. And tonight I'd like to share with the board more detailed information about what those mitigation strategies will look like in our schools. This portion of the presentation will be shared with our principals to share with both their staff and their school communities to make everyone aware of our plans as we begin school in just a short period of time.  So the mitigation strategies that you'll hear about tonight and that we have put in place are based on guidance from the national, state, and local level. And as we said earlier, we continue to partner with the Blue Ridge Health District and local medical professionals on a regular basis to stay informed of any change in guidance based on the levels of community transmission.  Daily COVID-19 screenings are a first step in the process. Each school day, parents are responsible for completing an at-home health screening of their child for COVID-19 symptoms prior to allowing them to board a school bus or to enter a school building. If they answer yes to any of the screening questions, they must keep their child home and notify the school. Employees are also required to perform a self-assessment for symptoms of COVID-19 before reporting to work.  If any employees answer yes to any screening questions, they must stay home and notify their supervisor. And finally, visitors are required to undergo a health screening for COVID-19 symptoms upon building entry. If they answer yes to any screening questions, they will not be granted access to that facility. We'll continue to require masks to be worn by all students, employees, and visitors when inside our school building or on our school buses, regardless of anyone's vaccination status.  In our buildings, we'll maintain at least three feet of physical distancing between students, and greater distancing, at least six feet, will be maintained when students are participating in moderate to vigorous physical activity, singing or playing a musical instrument. While outdoors, distance will be increased as much as an activity in space allowed, and as often as possible, we'll maintain a distance of at least six feet between adults and students.  Students are required to wash or sanitize their hands frequently during the day. Minimally, this includes each time they board a bus, enter a room, and go outside for recess and before they eat. All building entry points, classrooms, cafeterias, and buses have had sanitizer dispensers, have hand sanitizer dispensers to promote and support this requirement.  Throughout the day, custodial staff disinfect high touch surfaces. At night, custodians clean and disinfect classrooms and other spaces that were used during the day. Disinfecting wipes are available in all occupied classrooms for use by students and employees to sanitize high touch surfaces periodically throughout the day. Albemarle County has made investments and improvements to the ventilation systems in our school facilities.  Wherever possible, we've installed upgraded air filters and adjusted our mechanical systems to increase airflow from the outside. Every day, in an effort to improve indoor air quality, we perform a building air flush both before and after occupancy. Also, we have placed air purifiers with high efficiency particulate or HEPA filters in all classrooms, clinics, and school buses.  Each school day, breakfast and lunch are going to be available to all students free of charge, regardless of income level. Breakfast is available upon arrival and students eat the meal in their classroom. Lunch is served primarily in the cafeteria, though larger schools may set up additional serving lines in an alternate location. Depending on the school and grade level, students may eat lunch in the cafeteria, a classroom, another designated area of the building, or outside.  We encourage eating outdoors when the weather permits and if adequate supervision is available. Whether indoors or outdoors, we maximize physical distancing to the extent possible, maintaining a minimum of three feet between students. Once students are seated and ready to eat, they are permitted to remove their masks. And for contact tracing purposes, elementary students sit with the same group of peers at least one week at a time, and middle and high school students use a system to track where and with whom students are eating.  Our school buses are going to be operating at normal capacity this year. We've installed HEPA filters in all of our buses. They're located near the ceiling, a few rows behind the drive, and they remove dust, pollen, and virus particles from the air. We turn on the filters whenever the windows are closed. So on buses without air conditioning, we open windows during warm weather and turn off the HEPA filter. During cold weather, we close windows and turn on the HEPA filter.  On buses with air conditioning, we keep windows closed and run the HEPA filter at all times. All riders must sanitize their hands each time they board and exit the bus, and each bus has an adequate supply of sanitizer directly behind the driver's seat. The bus driver and all riders must wear a face mask, and each bus has a supply of mask in case a student forgets theirs. We assign seats to all riders, and this is also helpful for contact tracing and limits the number of exposures if we do have a positive case.  All visitors to our facilities are required to undergo a health screening for COVID-19 systems upon entry. They must sign in through the visitor management system in the school's main office and receive a volunteer visitors badge. They are not allowed in classrooms during the school day. They must wear a mask and keep at least six feet of distance between themselves and students. And during the school day, visitors are limited to those who are volunteering, attending a meeting, or visiting for another purpose approved by the principal.  A few final safety measures that we'd like to share with the board include the establishment of a central committee to review field trips and extracurricular activities in advance. We have turned off our water fountains, but left on the bottle fillers that are attached to those water fountains so students can refill their own bottles. Outdoor tents are in the process of being installed at each school to promote more outdoor activities. We limit the sharing of materials and equipment and students will have individual classroom supplies this year.  And if all those mitigation strategies, such as physical distancing, are in place, we will not have to place any additional restrictions on assemblies, large gatherings, or community use of our facilities. So we wanted to also talk about what happens if we do have illnesses within our school. So any student or employee who develops COVID-19-like symptoms at school or work will be excluded from school or work and referred to a healthcare provider to see if COVID-19 testing is warranted.  If a student becomes ill at school, we'll notify their parent or guardian who will need to pick them up promptly, usually within 60 minutes of the call. The student will wait in a designated clinic space until that time. And before a symptomatic student may return to school, the return to school plan must be completed by a healthcare provider. If we do have a confirmed case of COVID at one of our schools, we will exclude the person until that return to school work criteria has been met.  We'll follow established disinfection and ventilation protocols. We'll work with the health department's contact tracing team to identify close contacts. And we'll ask close contacts to quarantine and monitor for symptoms for 14 days from the last day of exposure. One important note is that fully vaccinated individuals do not need to follow quarantine procedures after a known exposure.  provided they do not develop symptoms. If a fully vaccinated person does develop symptoms, they should seek medical evaluation to see if testing is warranted. In general, people who are considered fully vaccinated two weeks after their second dose in a two-dose series, such as Pfizer or Moderna, or two weeks after a single-dose vaccine, such as Johnson & Johnson.  And finally, the superintendent of schools in consultation with local health officials will decide to close a school facility based on factors that are include are not limited to the extent of an identified outbreak at one of our facilities, the COVID-19 conditions in the community, absenteeism rates among staff and students, and local and or state ordinances and orders. If needed,  Individual schools will temporarily transition to fully virtual instruction for a length of time determined in coordination with the local health department. Such a decision would be based on the number of cases in the school and evidence of transmission in that particular school. We are currently developing a plan for how this transition would occur should it become necessary.  So I'd like to thank the board for their time tonight on this extended COVID update and mitigation plan. And Eileen and I would be happy to field any questions that you may have about anything that you've heard.

text: Thank you, Chair Page. This resolution of the Board of Education of Albemarle County Virginia School Board adopting order number 21-3 of the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia.  Whereas the school board recognizes that Albemarle County and the rest of the state of Virginia and the United States are in the midst of a worldwide COVID-19 pandemic that has resulted in more than 600,000 deaths in the United States. And whereas the school board has responded to the challenges brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, providing students and staff members with the technology and resources necessary to ensure the efficient delivery of instruction  virtually and in person. And whereas the school board has a substantial public interest in protecting the health and safety of its students, staff and community, and ensuring that the school division can provide staff and students with a safe and effective educational environment that supports student achievement.  And whereas school division staff at all levels are essential to the day-to-day operations of the school division and are responsible for the thorough and efficient education of all students and their social and emotional well-being. And whereas a surge of COVID-19 cases has recently occurred, largely resulting from the Delta variant, also known as B.1.617.2, a highly transmissible virus that impacts individuals regardless of age,  And whereas over 90% of COVID-19 infections are currently occurring in individuals who have not been vaccinated against COVID-19. And whereas the overwhelming scientific evidence has established that the vaccines authorized by the FDA for emergency use are safe and effective.  and recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for all individuals except children under 12 years of age and certain others, and whereas the school board has the responsibility to prevent the outbreak and spread of COVID-19 infections in its schools and other facilities, and whereas the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia has issued Order Number 21-3 pursuant to Virginia Code 44-146.21c,  mandating vaccines, vaccinations, or periodic testing for COVID-19 for the employees of the County of Albemarle. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the school board finds that there exists a public health emergency that requires action to safeguard students and staff against the risks of infection, illness, hospitalization, and death from COVID-19.  The school board adopts order number 21 dash three and will work in partnership with the county of Albemarle in the implementation of this order to control the spread of coven 19 in the school division and community.  The administration of the school division is directed to develop procedures for the implementation of this resolution that are based upon order number 21-2 as modified to reflect the specific operations of the school division and school board policies, regulations, and code of conduct, and otherwise take all other actions necessary to carry out this mandate.  The school board hereby delegates to the superintendent the authority to implement and modify vaccination and testing procedures based on changing conditions and to maintain conformance with the requirements of the CDC, Virginia Department of Health, Blue Ridge Health District, and other applicable health authorities.

text: Good evening, I'd like to provide a recap of the development of the proposed gender expansive policy before you this tonight's meeting. Virginia code section 22.1-22.3 enacted in 2020 requires all local school boards to adopt a policy regarding the treatment of transgender students by the start of the 21-22 school year.  that is consistent with or more comprehensive than the policy guidance published by the Virginia Board of Education as mandated by the statute. The ACPS proposed policy is aligned with the Virginia Code.  VDOE guidance and the holding of the United States Supreme, sorry about that, United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Grimm versus Gloucester County School Board that allows transgender students to utilize the bathroom and other facilities that correspond with their gender identities. This policy was presented to the school board at its meeting on Thursday, July 8th, 2021.  On July 28th, 2021, the ACPS conducted an informational session for the community following which the ACPS published FAQs, responded in writing to questions that were asked and reviewed and considered comments submitted to the school board. The draft policy before you now for approval contains a change prompted by concern Mr. Oberg raised at the last meeting. Mr. Oberg requested that the policy make clear  that implementation of the policy and resolution of issues that may arise there under will be the responsibility of the entire ACPS, including counselors, nurses, principals, and other administrators, and not classroom teachers alone. This addition is contained in the final section of the policy that discusses training and professional development. If you have any questions or concerns you would like me to address at this time, I'd be happy to do so.  And I appreciate your time and consideration.

text: Good evening, my name is Rosalyn Schmidt, Chief Operating Officer. So tonight I would like to present the scope of a proposed redistricting study. The item is for information tonight and will be on your consent agenda next meeting for action. So due to the overcrowding in the Crozet area, additional seats are being constructed at Crozet Elementary.  Brownsville elementary is overcrowded, but due to its already large size, further expansion was not recommended at that location. So students will need to be redistricted from Brownsville to Crozet.  The addition is under construction. If you have not been out that way, I encourage you to do so. It's quite a site. There's a lot of fun and good stuff going on, but it's quite the construction project. So that is scheduled to be complete one year from now for the 22-23 school year, and it will add 340 seats to Curzé Elementary.  We are recommending that the objective of this study be to find a solution to address the current and projected overcrowding at Brownsville Elementary, and the scope of the study will involve Brownsville and Crozet Elementary schools only. We propose the following guiding principles for the committee to consider as they select their recommendation, and they're outlined here, including a timeframe, comments around geography, transportation, and demographics,  And the last bullet, number one question we get asked in redistricting is grandfathering, whether current students can remain, and that is a decision by the board. We are proposing the committee be comprised of 10 members, four from each school, and then two members that are required by policy, one from the Long-Range Planning Advisory Committee, and one represented and recommended by the Office of Community Engagement.  These committee members would be supported by staff, including staff from planning, transportation, and the committee this year will be facilitated by Dr. McLaughlin.  Here's a little look about how the schedule will unfold. So again, this is for information tonight, but if the board ultimately approves at your next meeting, we would advertise and receive applications. That committee would meet in the September to December timeframes, meeting multiple times. Meetings would be open to the public. They would host community meetings for input, and then ultimately make a recommendation to the superintendent who will in turn make a recommendation to the board.  So turning the corner to 2022, that's when the school board would host a public hearing and ultimately vote on the recommendation. That allows transition activities to occur between February and the start of the next school year and the new boundaries would go in fact for the 22-23 school year.
